column7: is a city of republic significance in Kazakhstan on the northern bank of the Syr Darya river
column8: rented and administered by the Russian Federation. It was constructed to service the Baikonur Cosmodrome and was officially renamed Baikonur by Russian president Boris Yeltsin on December 20
column10: it was sometimes referred to as Звездоград (Zvezdograd)
column16: 776 (1999 Census results).The rented area is an ellipse measuring 90 kilometres (56 mi) east to west by 85 km (53 mi) north to south
column17: with the cosmodrome situated at the area's centre.

column2: i.e. "fertile land with many herbs") is a mining town 320 kilometres northeast of the present location
column3: near Dzhezkazgan in Kazakhstan's Karagandy Region. Starting with Vostok 1 in April 1961
column4: the launch site was given this name to cause confusion and keep the location secret. (The original Baikonur's residents took advantage of the confusion by ordering and receiving many scarce materials before government officials discovered the deception.) Baikonur's railway station predates the base and retains the old name of Tyuratam. This was the original Soviet railway station (railhead) on the Moscow to Tashkent Railway that the Cosmodrome was initially named after.

column1: The fortunes of the city have varied according to those of the Soviet or Russian space program and its Baikonur Cosmodrome. Foreign visitors need pre-approval from the Russian authorities to visit both the town of Baikonur itself and the Cosmodrome. Foreign visitors need to obtain a written approval which is completely separate from having a regular Russian Visa.
The Soviet government established the Nauchno-Issledovatel'skii Ispytatel'nyi Poligon N.5 (NIIIP-5)
column2: or Scientific-Research Test Range N.5 by its decree of 12 February 1955. The U-2 high-altitude reconnaissance plane found and photographed the Tyuratam missile test range (cosmodrome Baikonur) for the first time on 5 August 1957. See right for a composite satellite image of the early Tyuratam launch complex

column1: Baikonur features a cold desert climate (BWk). Summers are hot with July highs averaging slightly over 34 °C (93 °F)
column3: with longer periods of sustained below-freezing temperatures.

column2: near the Syr Darya River there is a large park with several sports and amusement facilities. Among these is a ferris wheel
column3: which is no longer in use. The park is located at coordinates 45°36′42″N 63°19′06″E.
